 Developing an Advanced PDF Content Retrieval with Large

Ronn Kevin A. Ru bio 
John Benedict B. To lenada  
Darlen e D. Bugas

Multi-class Classification of Human Emotion with Few-shot Learning
Anonymous ACL submission
Abstract
Image classification is one of the problem in 001
computer vision. Training the deep learning 002
model is a costly process in machine resources 003
and time. The convolutional neural network 004
(CNN) is most commonly used to build a struc- 005
ture of the deep learning models. Convolu- 006
tional neural network (CNN) can automatically 007
extract features and share weights from the pre- 008
trained model, which called transfer learning. 009
The transfer learning approach is used to im- 010
prove the performance of the deep learning 011
CNN model where classification works fairly 012
well with the smallest amount of computation 013
time and fewer machine resources. This study 014
evaluates the performance of deep learning 015
CNN model using transfer learning and fine- 016
tuning technique with few-shot learning task. 017
1 Introduction 018
Emotion is an individual state of mind. Emotions 019
can be reactions to internal inputs, such as thoughts, 020
or external events that are happening to the indi- 021
vidual(Apa). Human emotion has been studied by 022
many researchers in the field of human psychology 023
(Chae-Lin and Byung-Gyu, 2023). However, it is 024
widely used in human-computer interaction tasks 025
that allow companies to develop products that are 026
accessible to individuals and help them remain psy- 027
chologically healthy. Image classification tasks for 028
human emotion using deep learning are considered 029
modern approaches in computer vision. The deep 030
learning algorithm solves a wide range of problems 031
in classification tasks, such as text classification, 032
speech classification, video classification, and im- 033
age classification. The ability of deep learning to 034
recognize patterns and extract features from raw 035
data makes it easy to use. Therefore, the chal- 036
lenging part of using deep learning are the cost of 037
hardware and the time-consuming training process. 038
The training process may be time-consuming, but 039
it will have a positive impact on the performance 040of the model. This study evaluates the performance 041
of a deep learning model using transfer learning 042
techniques in a few-shot learning task. 043
2 Related Work 044
Previous work performed prototypical network ap- 045
proach for Few-shot learning and zero-shot learn- 046
ing task in Omniglot and miniImageNet dataset 047
(Jake Snell, 2017). Prototypical networks learn 048
a metric space in which classification can be per- 049
formed by computing distances to prototype rep- 050
resentations of each class. While transfer learning 051
used a pre-trained model that usually trained on a 052
large scale dataset, and apply the learned feature to 053
the new task. 054
The approach that performed in this study is 055
transfer learning method which is related to the 056
prototypical network that specifically designed for 057
few-shot learning task. The result of the previous 058
work give a good for overall performance with a 059
accuracy of 95 percent. Furthermore, the simplicity 060
and effectiveness of Prototypical Networks makes 061
it a promising approach for few-shot learning task. 062
3 Methods 063
I. Convolutional Neural Network(CNN) model is 064
used extensively in modern Machine Learning ap- 065
plications due to its ongoing record breaking ef- 066
fectiveness. A CNN typically has three layers: a 067
convolutional layer, a pooling layer, and a fully 068
connected layer. Convolutional layer computes the 069
value of the dot product of two matrices, one of 070
which is the set of learnable parameters known as a 071
kernel and the other is the restricted section of the 072
receptive field. The pooling layer, replaces the out- 073
put of the network at certain locations by deriving 074
a summary statistic of the nearby outputs. Lastly, 075
fully connected layer helps to map the representa- 076
tion between the input and the output. 077
II. Transfer learning is a machine learning tech- 078
nique whereby a model is trained and developed 079
